description: Community hospitals in the Northeast belonging to large nonprofit health systems with 10+ hospitals (e.g., members of systems like Northwell, Yale New Haven Health, Mass General Brigham).
Community hospitals in the South belonging to large nonprofit health systems such as Ascension, AdventHealth, or Baptist Health.
Community hospitals in the Midwest belonging to large nonprofit health systems such as Advocate Aurora, Mercy Health, or SSM Health.
Community hospitals in the West belonging to large nonprofit health systems such as Providence, CommonSpirit, or Intermountain Health.
Community hospitals in the South belonging to large for-profit chains such as HCA Healthcare, Tenet Healthcare, or Community Health Systems.
Community hospitals in the West operated by large for-profit chains such as HCA, Tenet, or Prime Healthcare.
Government-operated community hospitals in the South belonging to large public hospital systems such as county hospital districts or state systems.
Community hospitals in the Northeast belonging to regional nonprofit health systems with 2-9 hospitals serving a multi-county area.
Community hospitals in the South belonging to regional nonprofit health systems with 2-9 hospitals serving a metropolitan area or multi-county region.
Community hospitals in the Midwest belonging to regional nonprofit health systems with 2-9 hospitals.
Community hospitals in the West belonging to regional nonprofit health systems with 2-9 hospitals.
Community hospitals in the South belonging to regional for-profit hospital groups operating 2-9 facilities.
Community hospitals in the West belonging to regional for-profit hospital groups operating 2-9 facilities.
Government-operated community hospitals in the South belonging to county or municipal hospital districts with 2-9 facilities.
Standalone nonprofit community hospitals in the Northeast not affiliated with a multi-hospital system.
Standalone nonprofit community hospitals in the South not affiliated with a multi-hospital system.
Standalone nonprofit community hospitals in the Midwest not affiliated with a multi-hospital system.
Standalone for-profit community hospitals in the South, typically investor-owned single-facility operations.
Standalone county or municipal hospitals in the South operated by local government entities.
Standalone county or district hospitals in the West operated by local government entities.
Major teaching hospitals and academic medical centers in the Northeast affiliated with medical schools and operating within large nonprofit health systems.
Major teaching hospitals and academic medical centers in the South affiliated with medical schools and operating within large nonprofit health systems.
Major teaching hospitals and academic medical centers in the Midwest affiliated with medical schools and operating within large nonprofit health systems.
Major teaching hospitals and academic medical centers in the West affiliated with medical schools and operating within large nonprofit health systems.
Public university teaching hospitals in the South operated by state government, serving as academic medical centers for state medical schools.
Public university teaching hospitals in the Midwest operated by state government, serving as academic medical centers for state medical schools.
Teaching hospitals in the Northeast that are part of regional nonprofit health systems with 2-9 hospitals and maintain graduate medical education programs.
Teaching hospitals in the South that are part of regional nonprofit health systems with 2-9 hospitals and maintain graduate medical education programs.
Independent nonprofit Critical Access Hospitals in the Midwest â€” the region with the highest CAH concentration (46% of all U.S. CAHs), serving rural communities with 25 or fewer beds.
Independent nonprofit Critical Access Hospitals in the West, serving isolated rural communities across large geographic areas with 25 or fewer beds.
Independent nonprofit Critical Access Hospitals in the South, serving rural communities with limited healthcare infrastructure and 25 or fewer beds.
Independent nonprofit Critical Access Hospitals in the Northeast, found primarily in rural areas of Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire, and upstate New York.
Government-operated Critical Access Hospitals in the Midwest, typically county-owned facilities serving as the sole healthcare provider in rural counties.
Government-operated Critical Access Hospitals in the West, typically county or district-owned facilities serving remote rural communities.
Critical Access Hospitals in the Midwest affiliated with regional nonprofit health systems that provide management support while the facility retains CAH designation.
Federally Qualified Health Centers in the Northeast providing primary care to underserved populations in both urban and rural settings.
Federally Qualified Health Centers in the South providing primary care to underserved populations, particularly in states with high uninsured rates.
Federally Qualified Health Centers in the Midwest providing primary care to underserved populations in both urban centers and rural agricultural communities.
Federally Qualified Health Centers in the West providing primary care to underserved populations, including migrant farmworker communities and frontier areas.
Independent for-profit multi-provider physician practices in the Northeast, including multi-specialty groups and large single-specialty practices.
Independent for-profit multi-provider physician practices in the South, including multi-specialty groups and large single-specialty practices.
Independent for-profit multi-provider physician practices in the Midwest, including multi-specialty clinics and large single-specialty groups.
Independent for-profit multi-provider physician practices in the West, including multi-specialty groups and large single-specialty practices.
Physician practices in the South owned by or affiliated with large for-profit healthcare companies, including private-equity-backed physician groups.
Independent nonprofit physician practices in the Midwest, including physician-owned cooperative clinics and multispecialty group practices.
